UI_visible_response: Read 41 web pagesView Page Details“Second Yuan” refers to the second series of the Chinese currency Renminbi (RMB), which was introduced on March 1, 1955. This series was issued to replace the first series due to issues with the large face values and poor paper quality of the first series. The second series had a total of 11 different denominations, 13 varieties, and 15 versions. It was also the first series to include coins. The largest denomination in this series was the 10-yuan note. The ratio between the first series and the second series was 10,000:1, meaning that 10,000 units of the first series were equal to 1 unit of the second series. This series of currency was gradually phased out and replaced by the third series starting in 1962.CopyTry AgainShare
traffic_visible_response: “Second Yuan” refers to the second series of the Chinese currency Renminbi (RMB), which was introduced on March 1, 1955[^1^][^2^]. This series was issued to replace the first series due to issues with the large face values and poor paper quality of the first series[^1^]. The second series had a total of 11 different denominations, 13 varieties, and 15 versions[^2^]. It was also the first series to include coins[^2^]. The largest denomination in this series was the 10-yuan note[^1^]. The ratio between the first series and the second series was 10,000:1, meaning that 10,000 units of the first series were equal to 1 unit of the second series[^1^]. This series of currency was gradually phased out and replaced by the third series starting in 1962[^2^].
